The study found that air conditioning systems in buildings can circulate the virus, making it possible for people to contract the virus even if they are nowhere near an infected person. The study, which was conducted by a team of scientists from a leading research institute, found that the virus can be carried by tiny particles in the air, called aerosols, which can remain suspended in the air for hours. The scientists discovered that these aerosols can be circulated by air conditioning systems, which can make it possible for people in different parts of a building to contract the virus. This discovery has serious implications for public health, as it means that the virus can be transmitted in enclosed spaces, such as offices, schools, and hospitals, even if people are following social distancing guidelines. The study's lead author has called for urgent action to improve air filtration systems in buildings, to reduce the risk of airborne transmission. The study's findings have already been met with concern by public health officials, who are scrambling to update their guidance on how to prevent the spread of the virus. They are now urging people to avoid spending time in enclosed spaces with other people, and to ensure that buildings have adequate ventilation and air filtration systems. The study's lead author has also called for people to wear masks indoors, even if they are not in close contact with other people. This is because masks can help to filter out the virus from the air, reducing the risk of airborne transmission. The discovery that the COVID-19 virus is airborne is a major breakthrough in the fight against the pandemic. However, it also means that people need to be more vigilant than ever, and take every precaution to prevent the spread of the virus.
